rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's lesson is about learning to give instructions that work! 

Nobody follows rules all of the time. But *how* we give instructions can make things more happy and calm at home.

Negative instructions like, “Don’t touch that!” can make children feel bad. (They can make parents feel bad, too!)

Children are more likely to follow an instruction when it is worded in a positive way: "Please only touch things that belong to us!"

media_title.eng: How can giving positive instructions help you and your family? Tap play to learn more.

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings everyone.

Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them “stop fighting” or “stop playing with your food”, they don’t know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON’T want them to do.”

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are three tips to give positive instructions that work.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are three tips to give positive instructions that work.

section_1_text.eng:
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
But before you do that, connect to them, so they are more likely to listen.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Use your child’s name to get your child’s attention. Go down to their level. Make eye contact.

Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: “Please take your shoes off when you come inside, dear”.

section_2_text.eng:
Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do. 

Giving a transition warning helps when you are asking them to change activities!

section_2_extra_text.eng:
It can be difficult for your child to remember many instructions, so only give one at a time!

If possible, give a transition warning. For example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.”

section_3_text.eng:
Try using positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of “Don’t shout inside,” say “Talk in a quiet voice when we’re inside.”

ALWAYS praise your child for following your instruction. Remember that this will make them more likely to repeat the behaviour you have just praised them for, and listen to you next time!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.

Praise, praise, praise! Make sure you praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction.

Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

media_title.eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_3.name learned to give her children positive instructions.

media_transcript.eng:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learned about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “ don’t do this.” 
My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My child said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

quiz_1_question.eng: Your home activity is to give your child positive instructions today. Can you do it?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Of course, you can! It might feel awkward at first, but you will get it soon! Keep up the excellent effort.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Of course, you can! It might feel awkward at first, but you will get it soon! Keep up the excellent effort.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. It may take time to learn how to rephrase your requests. After the next request, you give your child, stop and imagine how it could be rephrased as a positive request. You’ve got this!
